     <article class="post-4035 post type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-activity-breaks category-connemara category-county-clare category-county-cork-destinations category-destinations category-fun-things-to-do-and-see category-galway category-kilkenny-city category-northern-ireland-destinations category-sightseeing_attractions_tours_ireland category-sligo category-surfing category-typically-irish category-uncategorized category-walking tag-accommodation tag-blarney-castle tag-clare-island tag-cork-city tag-dingle tag-dolphin tag-galway-connemara tag-glencolm-folk-village tag-hotels-2 tag-hotelsirelandcom tag-ireland tag-killarney-town tag-northwest tag-slieve-league tag-sligo-2 tag-tourism tag-travel tag-west tag-wild-atlantic-way" id="post-4035">
      <header class="entry-header">
       <h1 class="entry-title">
        Top 10 things to do on the Wild Atlantic Way
       </h1>
       <div class="comments-link">
        <a href="https://hotelsireland.com/blog/2015/01/23/top-10-things-wild-atlantic-way/#respond" title="Comment on Top 10 things to do on the Wild Atlantic Way">
         <span class="leave-reply">
          Leave a reply
         </span>
        </a>
       </div>
       <!-- .comments-link -->
      </header>
      <!-- .entry-header -->
      <div class="entry-content">
       <input class="jpibfi" type="hidden"/>
       <div class="simplesocialbuttons">
        <div class="simplesocialbutton ssb-button-googleplus">
         <!-- Google Plus One-->
         <div class="g-plusone" data-href="https://hotelsireland.com/blog/2015/01/23/top-10-things-wild-atlantic-way/" data-size="medium">
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="simplesocialbutton ssb-button-fblike">
         <!-- Facebook like-->
         <div id="fb-root">
         </div>
         <div class="fb-like" data-href="https://hotelsireland.com/blog/2015/01/23/top-10-things-wild-atlantic-way/" data-layout="button_count" data-send="false" data-show-faces="false">
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="simplesocialbutton ssb-button-twitter">
         <!-- Twitter-->
         <a class="twitter-share-button" data-text="Top 10 things to do on the Wild Atlantic Way" data-url="https://hotelsireland.com/blog/2015/01/23/top-10-things-wild-atlantic-way/" data-via="Hotelsireland" href="https://twitter.com/share" rel="nofollow">
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
       <p style="text-align: justify;">
        <img alt="medium-3N2A0604 (1)" class="aligncenter wp-image-4052 size-medium" height="200" src="https://hotelsireland.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/medium-3N2A0604-1-300x200.jpg" width="300"/>
       </p>
       <p style="text-align: justify;">
        The Wild Atlantic Way is a 2,500km route along the Irelands coastline in the west  passing through 9counties. Along the route from Co. Donegal to Co. Cork in the South you can discover many different activities, pretty towns and much more than just stunning views. Here are our Top 10 Things To Do on the Wild Atlantic Way to get the most out of your trip!
       </p>
       <p style="text-align: justify;">
        <span id="more-4035">
        </span>
       </p>
       <p style="text-align: justify;">
        <strong>
         Southwest
        </strong>
       </p>
       <ul>
        <li style="text-align: justify;">
         Cork City: One of the largest cities in Ireland, featuring one of the largest historic trading harbors in the world. Established by vikings in the 10th century, this port offers a great base to visit the 16th-century Blackrock Castle; the old city wall; historic Holy Trinity Church and more.
        </li>
       </ul>
       <p>
        <a href="https://hotelsireland.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/cork-city-2.jpg">
         <img alt="cork-city-2" class="aligncenter wp-image-4043 size-medium" height="199" src="https://hotelsireland.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/cork-city-2-300x199.jpg" width="300"/>
        </a>
       </p>
       <ul>
        <li style="text-align: justify;">
         Blarney Castle: This 15
         <sup>
          th
         </sup>
         century castle is just 15 minutes from Cork City and is very well preserved. For a gift of eloquence, make sure to lean backwards off the castle wall to kiss the Blarney Stone
         <img alt=";)" class="wp-smiley" src="https://hotelsireland.com/blog/wp-includes/images/smilies/icon_wink.gif"/>
        </li>
       </ul>
       <p>
        <a href="https://hotelsireland.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/Blarney-Castle-Cork.jpg">
         <img alt="Blarney Castle, Cork" class="aligncenter wp-image-4044 size-medium" height="225" src="https://hotelsireland.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/Blarney-Castle-Cork-300x225.jpg" width="300"/>
        </a>
       </p>
       <ul>
        <li style="text-align: justify;">
         Killarney Town: Voted Irelands tidiest town in 2011, the town is a great base to see several amazing sights nearby. Southwest of the city you can find the 15th-century Ross Castle and close-by you can also go for quick boat ride to Innishfallen Island to visit the Innishfallen Abbey founded in 640. Also, take a trip to Portmagee to catch the ferry to the Skellig Islands, home to a historic Christian monastery and the second largest puffin bird population in the world.
        </li>
       </ul>
       <p>
        <a href="https://hotelsireland.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/killarney.jpg">
         <img alt="killarney" class="aligncenter wp-image-4045 size-medium" height="157" src="https://hotelsireland.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/killarney-300x157.jpg" width="300"/>
        </a>
       </p>
       <p>
        <strong>
         The West
        </strong>
       </p>
       <ul>
        <li style="text-align: justify;">
         Dingle: Europes most westerly town, was once one of Irelands main trading ports. Nowadays, Dingles main activities include listening in to the local Irish music scene and a boat ride to say hi to Fungie the bottlenose dolphin.
        </li>
       </ul>
       <p>
        <a href="https://hotelsireland.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/Fungi-and-Boat.jpg">
         <img alt="Fungi-and-Boat" class="aligncenter wp-image-4046 size-medium" height="208" src="https://hotelsireland.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/Fungi-and-Boat-300x208.jpg" width="300"/>
        </a>
       </p>
       <ul>
        <li style="text-align: justify;">
         Galway: This town feels rather young, lively and modern  no wonder since a quarter of its population are students  but it is the only large city where visitors can hear Irish spoken on the streets. Find a colorful and culturally vibrant town with many small shops, pubs, restaurants and hotels.
        </li>
       </ul>
       <p>
        <a href="https://hotelsireland.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/Galway.jpg">
         <img alt="Galway" class="aligncenter wp-image-4047 size-medium" height="157" src="https://hotelsireland.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/Galway-300x157.jpg" width="300"/>
        </a>
       </p>
       <ul>
        <li style="text-align: justify;">
         Connemara: Situated at the western edge of Europe, this is one of the most beautiful, unspoiled places. Go for great walks in this real emerald of Ireland; see Kylemore Abbey and enjoy this distinct landscape, culture and heritage.
        </li>
       </ul>
       <p>
        <a href="https://hotelsireland.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/Connemara.jpg">
         <img alt="Connemara" class="aligncenter wp-image-4048 size-medium" height="157" src="https://hotelsireland.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/Connemara-300x157.jpg" width="300"/>
        </a>
       </p>
       <ul>
        <li style="text-align: justify;">
         Clare Island:Through the Middle Ages, the island belonged to the O Malley family. The ruins of an OMalley tower-house, are close to the pier at the eastern edge of the island.Another very prominent landmark of the island is the Clare Island Lighthouse, established in 1806.
        </li>
       </ul>
       <p>
        <strong>
         The Northwest
        </strong>
       </p>
       <ul>
        <li style="text-align: justify;">
         Sligos connection to the sea is obvious, as Sligo is well-known for its surfing spots, especially around Mullaghmore. Other things to do in Sligo town include pub visits, listening to live music, enjoyingrestaurants and going into small shops that have embraced a distinct, local ingredient  seaweed.
        </li>
       </ul>
       <p>
        <a href="https://hotelsireland.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/mullaghmore_head_sligo.jpg">
         <img alt="mullaghmore_head_sligo" class="aligncenter wp-image-4049 size-medium" height="157" src="https://hotelsireland.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/mullaghmore_head_sligo-300x157.jpg" width="300"/>
        </a>
       </p>
       <ul>
        <li style="text-align: justify;">
         Slieve League: The rugged County of Donegal offers its visitors a unique and beautiful scenery. Visit the 600m-high Slieve League, one of the highest sea cliffs in Europe. Also, go for a boat trip to see the rugged cliffs from below and perhaps spot some dolphins, seals and even whales. On top of the cliffs enjoy breath-taking views of the sea and the surrounding landscape. If youre up for it, steep hiking trails lead you even higher up the cliffs.
        </li>
       </ul>
       <p>
        <a href="https://hotelsireland.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/slieve-league.jpg">
         <img alt="slieve league" class="aligncenter wp-image-4050 size-medium" height="200" src="https://hotelsireland.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/slieve-league-300x200.jpg" width="300"/>
        </a>
       </p>
       <ul>
        <li style="text-align: justify;">
         Glencolm Folk Village: About 15 minutes from Slieve League you may find this traditional. living-history museum. Experience a real folk village and see traditional cottages, furnishings and artefacts that are exact replicas of the dwellings of local people in the 18th, 19th and 20th centuries.
        </li>
       </ul>
       <p>
        Enjoy your trip along the Wild Atlantic Way with many activities to do, things to try and sights to see and discover your very own West Coast of Ireland! Book your accommodation through:https://hotelsireland.com &amp; onhttps://hotelsireland.com/the-wild-atlantic-way/
       </p>
      </div>
